lines.text: Hey, hey, hey, Jimmy!
Yeah, well, here he is. What are you doing here?
[after trying to avoid being seen by Angel]
Buying some flowers, light bulbs, Johnny Mop, drag. You ain't working.
Ah, I figured I outta see Beth Van Zandt's movie The Breif; they adapted it from her novel.
Oh, any good?
Well, The Breif, The Firm, when are one of these ex lawyers going to write a book called The Fee?
Spare change?
[a homeless woman asks Angel]
No thanks, I'm fine.
[blowing her off]
Scotty, is there anything I can do for you?
Yeah, quit looking down on me for starters; not everybody can march to your Republican drum.
I don't vote any ticket. And I never lectured you in that way.
You have to promise me you'll use this to clean up and get a job.
[counting out some big money in front of Scotty]
So there's strings attached to this Mother Teresa moolah, huh?
As it applies to you, if Mother Teresa met a nut like you, she'd go out and buy herself a BMW.
You people love to demonize us homeless.

You people? Say, I'm your Godfather. And as far as being homeless, yeah, I have a little problem with that term in your case; maybe it's because I remember the eighteenth what trailer your dad co-signed for. What was that? The Travelin' Jack Kerouac museum? Of course that was long before the kayaks.
Come on, Jim, that wasn't my fault, that could have been huge. I just couldn't get the rights to the Jim Kerouac estate.
Yeah, well, some Republicans might have nailed that down before they bought the trailer. Oh, yeah, and then there was the tragedy with the trailer hitch; a design flaw, wasn't it?
You want my advice, as his Godfather - damn I'm getting tired of hearing that?
Yes, I want your advice.
It's not so much that you wreen't there, it's the way you over compensated because you weren't.
What? We spoiled him? We held him to a very tough standard.
Oh, please, Dennis, he got D's all threw college and what did you do? You bought him a more powerful computer.
But you need memory to compete in the academic race at all!
But is he? Is he in the academic race at all?
Well, he's not officially taking classes.
Oh, Officially! I forgot - you can earn college credits sleeping in the city flower beds and urinating in a parking structure.
All right! All right! He flunked out!
You shouldn't have been contributing one thin dime all those years to his shenanigans all those years he was goofing along with C's and D's.
That's what Peg said.
[suddenly struck by reality]
Dad, Jim, you're hardwired to this dualism thing. Mom, you too. Good, bad, pain, pleasure, it's all one; are not this prison and Temple equally conducive to sitting and meditating?
[after getting out of jail, still dressed like a Buddhist monk]
You might find sitting a bit mroe painful in prison...
